docs.title: THD-Spatial GitHub Template
docs.text: Welcome to the THD-Spatial GitHub Template documentation! This template helps group members create standardized, open-source ready repositories.

docs.title: Quick Overview
docs.text: This template repository provides a complete starting point for open-sourcing projects under the THD-Spatial organization. It includes essential files, guidelines, and a comprehensive checklist to ensure your project meets all requirements.

docs.title: What's Included
docs.text:
• Essential Documentation Templates: LICENSE, README, CONTRIBUTING, CODE_OF_CONDUCT
  • Open Source Checklist: Step-by-step verification of requirements
  • Git LFS Configuration: For managing large data files
  • Best Practices: Guidelines for creating high-quality open source projects

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Use this template: Click "Use this template" button on GitHub
  2. Customize files: Update all template files for your specific project
  3. Complete checklist: Use OPEN_SOURCE_CHECKLIST.md to track progress
  4. Make it public: Once all requirements are met, publish your repository

docs.title: Use Docstrings
docs.text:
Document your code properly:

def process_spatial_data(data, resolution=30, method='bilinear'):
    """
    Process spatial data with specified resolution and interpolation method.

    This function resamples spatial data to a target resolution using
    various interpolation methods. It handles both raster and vector data.

    Args:
        data (xarray.DataArray): Input spatial data to process
        resolution (int, optional): Target resolution in meters. Defaults to 30.
        method (str, optional): Interpolation method. Options are 'bilinear',
            'nearest', or 'cubic'. Defaults to 'bilinear'.

    Returns:
        xarray.DataArray: Resampled spatial data at target resolution

    Raises:
        ValueError: If resolution is negative or method is invalid
        TypeError: If data is not an xarray.DataArray

    Examples:
        >>> import xarray as xr
        >>> data = xr.DataArray([...])
        >>> processed = process_spatial_data(data, resolution=10)
        >>> print(processed.shape)
        (100, 100)

    Note:
        This function requires GDAL to be installed for certain interpolation methods.

    See Also:
        - resample_raster: For more advanced resampling options
        - aggregate_data: For aggregation instead of interpolation
    """
    pass

import pytest
from your_project import process_data

def test_process_data_basic():
    """Test basic data processing."""
    input_data = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
    result = process_data(input_data)
    assert len(result) == 5
    assert all(isinstance(x, float) for x in result)

def test_process_data_empty():
    """Test empty input handling."""
    result = process_data([])
    assert result == []

def test_process_data_invalid_type():
    """Test invalid input type."""
    with pytest.raises(TypeError):
        process_data("not a list")

@pytest.mark.parametrize("input_val,expected", [
    ([1, 2, 3], 3),
    ([1], 1),
    ([], 0),
])
def test_process_data_length(input_val, expected):
    """Test processing various lengths."""
    result = process_data(input_val)
    assert len(result) == expected

docs.title: Write Good Commit Messages
docs.text:
Follow conventional commits format:

<type>(<scope>): <subject>

<body>

<footer>

Types: - feat: New feature - fix: Bug fix - docs: Documentation only - style: Formatting (no code change) - refactor: Code restructuring - test: Adding/updating tests - chore: Maintenance

Examples:

feat(processing): add support for NetCDF4 files

Implements NetCDF4 file reader using xarray. Supports
chunked reading for large files and automatic CRS detection.

Closes #123

fix(utils): handle missing values in coordinate transformation

Previously, missing values caused errors. Now they are handled
gracefully by filtering before transformation.

Fixes #456

# Security Policy

## Supported Versions

Currently supported versions:

| Version | Supported          |
| ------- | ------------------ |
| 1.1.x   | :white_check_mark: |
| 1.0.x   | :white_check_mark: |
| < 1.0   | :x:                |

## Reporting a Vulnerability

We take security seriously. If you discover a security vulnerability, please follow these steps:

### DO NOT

- ❌ Open a public GitHub issue
- ❌ Discuss the vulnerability publicly
- ❌ Disclose the vulnerability before it's been fixed

### DO

1. **Email** security@THD-Spatial-group.org with:
   - Description of the vulnerability
   - Steps to reproduce
   - Potential impact
   - Any suggested fixes

2. **Encrypt** sensitive information using our PGP key (if available)

3. **Wait** for acknowledgment (usually within 48 hours)

### What to Expect

- **Acknowledgment** within 48 hours
- **Assessment** within 1 week
- **Fix timeline** discussed based on severity
- **Credit** in security advisory (if desired)
- **Coordinated disclosure** once fix is available

### Security Update Process

1. Vulnerability confirmed
2. Fix developed and tested
3. Security advisory drafted
4. Patch released
5. Advisory published
6. Users notified

## Security Best Practices for Users

When using this project:

- Keep dependencies up to date
- Use released versions, not development branches
- Follow security guidelines in documentation
- Report suspicious activity

Thank you for helping keep our project secure!

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text: A Code of Conduct establishes ground rules for behavior and creates a welcoming, inclusive environment for all contributors.

docs.title: Why a Code of Conduct Matters
docs.text:
A Code of Conduct:

  • Creates safety - Defines acceptable behavior and consequences
  • Encourages participation - Makes everyone feel welcome
  • Sets standards - Establishes community expectations
  • Prevents issues - Proactively addresses potential problems
  • Provides recourse - Gives reporting procedures for violations

Best Practice

Even for small projects, having a Code of Conduct signals that you value a positive community environment.

docs.title: Contributor Covenant
docs.text: The Contributor Covenant is the most widely-used Code of Conduct in open source.

docs.title: Why Choose Contributor Covenant?
docs.text:
• ✅ Industry standard (used by thousands of projects)
  • ✅ Well-tested and proven effective
  • ✅ Available in multiple languages
  • ✅ Regularly updated
  • ✅ Clear and comprehensive

## Code of Conduct

docs.title: Our Pledge
docs.text:
Defines the commitment to creating an open and welcoming environment.

We as members, contributors, and leaders pledge to make participation in our
community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body
size, visible or invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender
identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status,
nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, or sexual
identity and orientation.

docs.title: Examples of Positive Behavior:
docs.text:
• Using welcoming and inclusive language
  • Being respectful of differing viewpoints
  • Gracefully accepting constructive criticism
  • Focusing on what's best for the community
  • Showing empathy towards others

docs.title: Examples of Unacceptable Behavior:
docs.text:
• Trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, personal attacks
  • Public or private harassment
  • Publishing others' private information without permission
  • Other conduct inappropriate in a professional setting

docs.title: Enforcement Responsibilities
docs.text:
Defines maintainer responsibilities:

  • Clarifying and enforcing standards
  • Taking appropriate corrective action
  • Removing/rejecting contributions that violate the Code of Conduct

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: Applies to: - Project spaces (issues, pull requests, etc.) - Public spaces when representing the project - Official project communication channels

docs.title: Enforcement
docs.text: Describes the reporting process and consequences.

docs.title: Enforcement Guidelines
docs.text: The Contributor Covenant includes tiered consequences:

docs.title: 1. Correction
docs.text:
Impact: Minor violation or misunderstanding

Consequence: Private warning with explanation, possibly public apology requested

docs.title: 2. Warning
docs.text:
Impact: Single incident or series of actions

Consequence: Warning with consequences for continued behavior, temporary interaction ban

docs.title: 3. Temporary Ban
docs.text:
Impact: Serious violation or sustained inappropriate behavior

Consequence: Temporary ban from interaction for specified period

docs.title: 4. Permanent Ban
docs.text:
Impact: Pattern of violations, harassment, or aggression

Consequence: Permanent ban from project community

Options for reporting violations:

Privacy

1. **Receive report**: Acknowledge within 24 hours
2. **Investigate**: Gather information from all parties
3. **Decide**: Determine if violation occurred and severity
4. **Act**: Apply appropriate consequence
5. **Document**: Record incident and action taken
6. **Follow-up**: Check with reporter and monitor situation

## Research Conduct

In addition to our Code of Conduct, we expect:

- **Data integrity**: No fabrication or falsification of data
- **Attribution**: Proper credit for contributions and ideas
- **Collaboration**: Respect for collaborative research norms
- **Confidentiality**: Respect for unpublished work and data
- **Authorship**: Fair and transparent authorship decisions

docs.title: Do small projects need a Code of Conduct?
docs.text: Yes. It signals professional standards and welcoming environment regardless of project size.

docs.title: What if we never get reports?
docs.text: That's usually good! Having a CoC prevents issues and sets expectations even if never invoked.

docs.title: Can we modify the Contributor Covenant?
docs.text: Yes, but only minor modifications are recommended. Major changes defeat the purpose of using a standard.

docs.title: Who enforces the Code of Conduct?
docs.text: Project maintainers, though larger projects may have dedicated moderation teams.

docs.title: What if a maintainer violates the Code?
docs.text: They should be held to the same standards. Consider having escalation path to organization leaders.

docs.title: Template Structure
docs.text:
Here's a comprehensive template for CONTRIBUTING.md:

# Contributing to [Project Name]

Thank you for your interest in contributing! We welcome contributions from the community.

## Code of Conduct

This project adheres to a [Code of Conduct](CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md). By participating, you are expected to uphold this code.

## How Can I Contribute?

### Reporting Bugs

Before creating bug reports, please check existing issues to avoid duplicates.

**How to submit a bug report:**

1. Use the issue tracker
2. Use a clear and descriptive title
3. Describe the exact steps to reproduce
4. Provide specific examples
5. Describe the observed behavior vs expected behavior
6. Include screenshots if applicable
7. Include your environment details (OS, Python version, etc.)

### Suggesting Enhancements

Enhancement suggestions are tracked as GitHub issues.

**How to submit an enhancement:**

1. Use the issue tracker
2. Use a clear and descriptive title
3. Provide a detailed description of the proposed functionality
4. Explain why this enhancement would be useful
5. List any similar features in other projects

### Pull Requests

1. **Fork** the repository
2. **Create a branch** for your changes: `git checkout -b feature/my-feature`
3. **Make your changes** following the coding standards below
4. **Write tests** for your changes
5. **Run tests** to ensure everything passes
6. **Commit** with descriptive messages
7. **Push** to your fork: `git push origin feature/my-feature`
8. **Open a Pull Request** with a clear description

## Development Setup

\`\`\`bash
# Clone your fork
git clone https://github.com/your-username/project-name.git
cd project-name

python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\\Scripts\\activate

## Coding Standards

### Python Style Guide

- Follow [PEP 8](https://pep8.org/)
- Use 4 spaces for indentation (no tabs)
- Maximum line length: 88 characters (Black formatter default)
- Use meaningful variable and function names

### Code Formatting

We use automated formatters:

\`\`\`bash
# Format code with Black
black .

# Sort imports with isort
isort .

# Check types with mypy (if applicable)
mypy src/
\`\`\`

### Documentation

- Add docstrings to all public functions and classes
- Use Google-style or NumPy-style docstrings
- Update README.md if adding new features
- Add comments for complex logic

Example docstring:

\`\`\`python
def process_data(data: pd.DataFrame, threshold: float = 0.5) -> pd.DataFrame:
    """
    Process input data by applying threshold filtering.

    Args:
        data: Input DataFrame containing raw data
        threshold: Minimum value to retain (default: 0.5)

    Returns:
        Filtered DataFrame with values above threshold

    Raises:
        ValueError: If threshold is negative
    """
    pass
\`\`\`

## Commit Message Guidelines

Follow the [Conventional Commits](https://www.conventionalcommits.org/) specification:

\`\`\`
<type>(<scope>): <subject>

<body>

<footer>
\`\`\`

**Types:**
- `feat`: New feature
- `fix`: Bug fix
- `docs`: Documentation changes
- `style`: Formatting changes (no code change)
- `refactor`: Code refactoring
- `test`: Adding or updating tests
- `chore`: Maintenance tasks

**Examples:**

\`\`\`
feat(parser): add support for GeoTIFF files

fix(processing): handle missing values correctly

docs: update installation instructions

test(utils): add tests for coordinate transformation
\`\`\`

## Testing

All code changes should include tests.

### Running Tests

\`\`\`bash
# Run all tests
pytest

# Run with coverage
pytest --cov=src --cov-report=html

# Run specific test file
pytest tests/test_feature.py
\`\`\`

### Writing Tests

\`\`\`python
import pytest
from myproject import my_function

def test_my_function_basic():
    """Test basic functionality."""
    result = my_function(input_data)
    assert result == expected_output

def test_my_function_edge_case():
    """Test edge case handling."""
    with pytest.raises(ValueError):

\`\`\`

1. **Automated checks** must pass (tests, linting, type checking)
2. **Code review** by at least one maintainer

docs.title: Git LFS (Large File Storage)
docs.text: Git LFS is essential for managing large files in your repository, particularly data files common in spatial research projects.

docs.title: Why Git LFS?
docs.text:
Standard Git is designed for text files and struggles with large binary files:

❌ Without Git LFS: - Repository becomes bloated - Clone/fetch operations are slow - Every version of large files stored in history - GitHub has file size limits (100 MB per file)

✅ With Git LFS: - Large files stored separately - Fast clone/fetch operations - Only download files when needed - Efficient storage of file versions

Important

Git LFS is required for THD-Spatial repositories that contain large data files.

docs.title: When to Use Git LFS
docs.text:
Use Git LFS for:

  • Data files: NetCDF, HDF5, GeoTIFF, Zarr
  • Media files: Images, videos, audio
  • Binary files: Compiled code, archives
  • Large documents: Large PDFs, presentations
  • Machine learning models: Model weights, checkpoints

Typical spatial data file formats:

*.nc          # NetCDF files
*.tif, *.tiff # GeoTIFF files
*.hdf, *.h5   # HDF5 files
*.zarr        # Zarr stores
*.shp         # Shapefiles
*.gdb         # Geodatabases
*.las, *.laz  # LiDAR data

docs.title: Linux (Ubuntu/Debian)
docs.text:
sudo apt-get install git-lfs
git lfs install

docs.title: macOS
docs.text:
brew install git-lfs
git lfs install

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
1. Download installer from git-lfs.github.com
  2. Run the installer
  3. Open Git Bash and run: git lfs install

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
git lfs version
# Output: git-lfs/3.4.0 (GitHub; linux amd64; go 1.21.0)

docs.title: Adding LFS to Existing Repository
docs.text:
# Navigate to your repository
cd your-repo

# Install Git LFS for this repository
git lfs install

# Track file types
git lfs track "*.nc"
git lfs track "*.tif"
git lfs track "*.h5"

# Add .gitattributes (created by lfs track)
git add .gitattributes
git commit -m "Configure Git LFS"

docs.title: Track Specific Files
docs.text:
# Track by extension
git lfs track "*.nc"

# Track specific file
git lfs track "data/large_dataset.tif"

# Track all files in directory
git lfs track "data/**"

# Track by pattern
git lfs track "**/satellite_*.tif"

docs.title: View Tracked Patterns
docs.text:
# List tracked patterns
git lfs track

# Check if file is tracked
git lfs ls-files

docs.title: Adding Files
docs.text:
Once tracking is configured, add files normally:

# Add large file (will be handled by LFS)
git add data/large_file.nc
git commit -m "Add large dataset"
git push origin main

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
Git LFS uses .gitattributes to track patterns:

# NetCDF files
*.nc filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text
*.nc4 filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text

# GeoTIFF files
*.tif filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text
*.tiff filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text

# HDF5 files
*.hdf filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text
*.hdf5 filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text
*.h5 filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text

# Zarr stores
*.zarr/** filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text

# Shapefiles
*.shp filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text
*.shx filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text
*.dbf filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text

# LiDAR data
*.las filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text
*.laz filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text

# Images
*.png filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text
*.jpg filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text
*.jpeg filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text

# Archives
*.zip filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text
*.tar.gz filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text

# Model files
*.h5 filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text
*.pkl filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text
*.model filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text

docs.title: Cloning LFS Repository
docs.text:
# Clone repository (LFS files downloaded automatically)
git clone https://github.com/THD-Spatial/your-repo.git

# Or clone without downloading LFS files initially
GIT_LFS_SKIP_SMUDGE=1 git clone https://github.com/THD-Spatial/your-repo.git

# Then download specific LFS files
git lfs pull --include="data/*.nc"

docs.title: Downloading LFS Files
docs.text:
# Download all LFS files
git lfs pull

# Download specific files
git lfs pull --include="data/specific_file.nc"

# Download files matching pattern
git lfs pull --include="data/*.tif"

# Exclude certain files
git lfs pull --exclude="data/temp/*"

docs.title: Checking LFS Status
docs.text:
# List LFS files
git lfs ls-files

# Show LFS environment
git lfs env

# Show storage usage
git lfs status

docs.title: Migrating Existing Files
docs.text:
If you have large files already committed:

# Migrate existing files to LFS
git lfs migrate import --include="*.nc"

# Migrate and rewrite history
git lfs migrate import --include="*.nc" --everything

# Force push after migration
git push origin --force --all

Warning

Rewriting history with --everything changes commit hashes. Coordinate with collaborators.

docs.title: Storage Limits
docs.text: GitHub provides: - 1 GB free LFS storage per account - 1 GB/month free bandwidth - Additional data packs available

docs.title: Checking Usage
docs.text: View LFS usage in GitHub repository settings under "Billing".

docs.title: Release Assets
docs.text:
Critical

Files tracked by Git LFS are not included in release source archives.

To include LFS files in releases:

# Create release and upload LFS files separately
gh release create v1.0.0 \
  --title "Release 1.0.0" \
  --notes "Release notes" \
  data/dataset.nc data/model.h5

Or use GitHub Actions:

name: Release
on:
  release:
    types: [created]

jobs:
  upload-assets:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
        with:
          lfs: true

      - name: Upload LFS files to release
        uses: softprops/action-gh-release@v1
        with:
          files: |
            data/*.nc
            data/*.tif

docs.title: DO:
docs.text: ✅ Track all files over 10 MB ✅ Commit .gitattributes file ✅ Use consistent patterns ✅ Document which files are LFS-tracked ✅ Verify LFS tracking before committing: git lfs ls-files ✅ Include LFS setup in installation instructions

docs.title: DON'T:
docs.text: ❌ Track small files (<1 MB) with LFS (unnecessary overhead) ❌ Forget to run git lfs install on new machines ❌ Mix LFS and non-LFS tracking for same file type ❌ Assume LFS files will be in release archives ❌ Track frequently-changing files (if possible)

docs.title: Files Not Tracked
docs.text:
# Check if pattern is tracked
git lfs track

# Manually mark file as LFS
git lfs track "path/to/file.nc"
git add .gitattributes path/to/file.nc
git commit --amend

docs.title: Bandwidth Exceeded
docs.text:
# Clone without LFS files
GIT_LFS_SKIP_SMUDGE=1 git clone <repo>

docs.title: Fixing Already-Committed Large Files
docs.text:
# Track with LFS
git lfs track "*.nc"

# Migrate existing files
git lfs migrate import --include="*.nc" --everything

# Force push (warn collaborators first!)
git push origin --force --all

docs.title: Why Licensing Matters
docs.text:
A license is required for all public repositories in the THD-Spatial organization. Without a license, your code is under exclusive copyright by default, meaning others cannot legally use, copy, modify, or distribute your work.

Critical Requirement

You cannot make your repository public under THD-Spatial without including a LICENSE file.

docs.title: Choosing a License
docs.text: Different licenses suit different needs. Here's a guide to help you choose:

docs.title: Permissive Licenses
docs.text: Allow maximum freedom for users with minimal restrictions.

docs.title: MIT License
docs.text:
• Best for: Most projects, especially libraries
  • Allows: Commercial use, modification, distribution, private use
  • Requires: License and copyright notice
  • Limitations: No liability or warranty
✅ Simple and permissive
✅ Most commonly used license
✅ Easy to understand
✅ Compatible with most projects

docs.title: Apache License 2.0
docs.text:
• Best for: Projects concerned with patent rights
  • Allows: Same as MIT, plus explicit patent grant
  • Requires: License notice, state changes, copyright notice
  • Limitations: No liability, warranty, or trademark use
✅ Includes patent protection
✅ Good for projects with contributors
✅ Widely used in industry
⚠️ More complex than MIT

docs.title: BSD 3-Clause License
docs.text:
• Best for: Academic and research projects
  • Allows: Commercial use, modification, distribution
  • Requires: License notice, copyright notice
  • Limitations: Cannot use contributors' names for endorsement
✅ Simple and well-established
✅ Common in academia
✅ Similar to MIT

docs.title: Copyleft Licenses
docs.text: Require derivative works to use the same license.

docs.title: GNU GPL v3
docs.text:
• Best for: Projects you want to keep open source
  • Allows: Commercial use, modification, distribution
  • Requires: Disclose source, same license, state changes
  • Limitations: Strong copyleft - derivatives must be GPL
⚠️ Strong copyleft requirement
⚠️ May limit adoption in commercial projects
✅ Ensures derivatives remain open source
✅ Good for preventing proprietary forks

docs.title: GNU LGPL v3
docs.text:
• Best for: Libraries that might be used in proprietary software
  • Allows: Linking from proprietary code
  • Requires: Disclose source of library, same license for library
  • Limitations: Modifications to library must be LGPL
✅ More permissive than GPL
✅ Allows use in proprietary software
⚠️ More complex licensing requirements

docs.title: Creative Commons
docs.text: For non-software content (documentation, datasets, media).

docs.title: CC BY 4.0
docs.text:
• Best for: Documentation, datasets, educational materials
  • Allows: Sharing and adaptation with attribution
  • Requires: Attribution, indicate if changes made
✅ Good for data and documentation
✅ Requires credit to original author
⚠️ Not recommended for software code

docs.title: Recommended Licenses by Project Type
docs.text: Project Type Recommended License Why Python/R Library MIT or Apache 2.0 Maximum adoption, simple Data Processing Tool MIT Easy for users to integrate Research Dataset CC BY 4.0 Appropriate for data Full Application MIT or GPL-3.0 MIT for permissive, GPL to ensure openness Documentation CC BY 4.0 Standard for documentation

docs.text:

  2. Copy the full license text

  5. [fullname] → Your name or "THD-Spatial Group"

docs.text:

# Licensed under the MIT License - see LICENSE file for details

docs.title: Can I change the license later?
docs.text: You can change to a more permissive license, but making it more restrictive is problematic since others may have already used your code under the permissive license.

docs.title: Can I use multiple licenses?
docs.text: Yes, you can dual-license or use different licenses for different parts (e.g., MIT for code, CC BY for data).

docs.title: What if I use code from other projects?
docs.text: You must comply with their licenses. MIT and Apache are usually compatible, but GPL code requires your project to be GPL.

docs.title: Do I need permission from all contributors?
docs.text: If others have contributed code, they hold copyright too. Get agreement before changing licenses, or use a Contributor License Agreement (CLA).

docs.text:

Apache 2.0 ✅ Compatible with: GPL-3.0+, MIT, BSD
GPL-3.0 ⚠️ Requires: Derivative work to be GPL-3.0
BSD ✅ Compatible with: Most licenses
